posts.name: pribusin
posts.cooked: We are using a NEO550 with an ultraplanetary gearbox for a small mechanism in a tight space.  We just burnt up the motor after it stalled and we’re looking at options to replace it with another motor that’s a bit more robust.  We’re thinking maybe the HD Hex motor but I’m not sure if it can be controlled with a SparkMAX. Any suggestions are appreciated.

Yes you can do that but just don’t, as far as I am aware the HD Hex Motor is in fact less powerful than a Neo 550, being brushed and physically smaller. Word on the street is to really current limit your 550s or they will stall out and cook themselves.

posts.name: ben gates
posts.cooked: Can a SparkMAX even control an HD Hex motor at all? Usually brushless controllers are incompatible with brushed cans, at least that’s how RC systems work.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
rainyskies:

as far as I am aware the HD Hex Motor is in fact less powerful than a Neo 550

Way less. VEX’s motor testing clocked it at 332 W vs. 28 W. Plan accordingly.

banjogates:

Can a SparkMAX even control an HD Hex motor at all? Usually brushless controllers are incompatible with brushed cans, at least that’s how RC systems work.

SPARK MAX isn’t the average brushless controller. It can do both.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: pribusin
posts.cooked: We are definitely looking at current limiting now. We’re shooting for 10A limit initially. During testing we’re using the REV Hardware client to run the NEO550 with a SparkMAX . Is that adequate to set current limit with?  I presume hte SparkMAX handles the actual current limiting.
Not a programmer, I do not know, but i’m sure the helpful people of CD may be able to offer more advice

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: Rev’s locked rotor testing with the Neo 550 says it can survive a stall with a 20A current limit for at least one match, 220 seconds. We run our Neo 550s with a 20A limit normally.  If that isn’t enough torque we change gearbox ratios or swap in a regular Neo. At the default spark max current limit of 80A you’ll smoke a Neo 550 in just a few seconds of stall, again according to Rev’s testing.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
The Spark Max manages current limit.  Make sure to do a “persist parameters” after you change the current limit, and/or set it in your code.  Otherwise the current limit will go back to 80A at next boot.

Torque is directly proportional to current limit.  The spec sheet for a NEO 550 calls out 0.97 Nm of torque at 100A, so at 10A maximum torque is 0.097 Nm.  It’s safe to run up to 20A current limit which is about 0.2 Nm.

Running a current limit will limit motor power.  Take a look at the curve on the data sheet. https://www.revrobotics.com/content/docs/REV-21-1651- DS .pdf A 20A limit reduces max power output to around 160W, at 9k RPM .    That’s still pretty good for a tiny motor.
